title-group.article-title: Maintenance of World Health Organization Risk Drinking Level Reductions and Posttreatment Functioning Following a Large Alcohol Use Disorder Clinical Trial

aff.institution: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

aff.named-content: Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences

author-notes.corresp: *Reprint requests: Katie Witkiewitz, PhD, Department of Psychology, University of New Mexico, MSC 03â2220, Albuquerque, NM 87131; Tel.: 505â925â2334; Fax: 505â277â1394; Eâmail: katiew@unm.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© 2019 The Authors. Alcoholism: Clinical & Experimental Research published by Wiley Periodicals, Inc. on behalf of Research Society on Alcoholism

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is nonâcommercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Reductions in the World Health Organization (WHO) risk drinking levels have been proposed as an alternative primary outcome for alcohol clinical trials. Yet, little is known about whether reductions in WHO risk drinking levels can be maintained over time. The current study examined whether reductions in WHO risk drinking levels were maintained for up to 1Â year following treatment, and whether reductions over time were associated with improvements in functioning.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Secondary data analysis of individuals with alcohol dependence (nÂ =Â 1,226) enrolled in the COMBINE study, a multisite, randomized, placeboâcontrolled clinical trial. Logistic regression was used to examine the maintenance of endâofâtreatment WHO risk level reductions and WHO risk level reductions at the 1âyear followâup. Repeatedâmeasures mixed models were used to examine the association between WHO risk level reductions and functional outcomes over time.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Achieving at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction in risk by the end of treatment was significantly associated with WHO risk level reductions at the 1âyear followâup assessment (pÂ <Â 0.001). Among individuals who achieved at least a 1âlevel reduction by the end of treatment, 85.5% reported at least a 1âlevel reduction at the 1âyear followâup. Among individuals who achieved at least a 2âlevel reduction by the end of treatment, 77.8% reported at least a 2âlevel reduction at the 1âyear followâup. WHO risk level reductions were associated with significantly lower alcohol consumption, better physical health (pÂ <Â 0.01), and fewer alcoholârelated consequences (pÂ <Â 0.001) up to 1Â year following treatment.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Oneâ and 2âlevel reductions in WHO risk levels during alcohol treatment were maintained after treatment and associated with better functioning over time. These findings support the use of the WHO risk level reductions as an outcome measure that reflects clinically significant improvement in how individuals seeking treatment for alcohol use disorder feel and function.

kwd-group.kwd: World Health Organization Risk Drinking Levels

award-group.funding-source: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

body.p: For individuals treated for alcohol use disorder (AUD), engaging in some level of drinking following treatment is common (Hunt etÂ al., 1971; Maisto etÂ al., 2018; Witkiewitz and Masyn, 2008). Sustained abstinence has long been considered the optimal outcome of AUD treatment (Betty Ford Institute Consensus Panel, 2007; Mann etÂ al., 2017), and most research historically focused on abstinence as a primary measure of treatment outcomes (e.g., percent days abstinent from alcohol; Anton etÂ al., 2006; Maisto etÂ al., 2016). Yet, individuals seeking treatment for AUD are increasingly interested in drinking reduction goals (DeMartini etÂ al., 2014; Haug etÂ al., 2018; Ryan etÂ al., 2017) and AUD treatment professionals have become more accepting of patients' drinking reduction goals (Davis and Rosenberg, 2013; Rosenberg and Davis, 1994). Given a growing interest in drinking reduction as a goal of AUD treatment (van Amsterdam and van den Brink, 2013; Mann etÂ al., 2017), examining whether drinking reductions are maintained over time and associated with improvements in patients' functioning is an important question for AUD treatment outcomes research.

sec.title: Primary Measures of AUD Treatment Outcomes
sec.p: The Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) draft guidance on the development of alcohol treatment medications (Food and Drug Administration, 2015) recommended 2 potential AUD treatment outcomes (i.e., end points) for medication development: (i) sustained abstinence; or (ii) no heavy drinking days, with heavy drinking days defined as more than 3 drinks in a day for women and 4 drinks in a day for men (National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, 2005). The European Medicines Agency (EMA, 2010) recommends abstinence as a primary end point, but acknowledges the utility of drinking reduction end points for alcohol clinical trials, including reductions in total alcohol consumption, in heavy drinking days, or in the World Health Organization (WHO) risk drinking levels (WHO, 2000), which are defined by sexâspecific limits on the number of grams (g) of alcohol consumed per day. Specifically, as shown in Fig.Â 1, individuals can be abstinent (0Â g males/females), low risk (1 to 40Â g males/1 to 20Â g females), medium risk (41 to 60Â g males/21 to 40Â g females), high risk (61 to 100Â g males/41 to 60Â g females), or very high risk (101+Â g males/61+Â g females). Importantly, guidance from both the FDA and the EMA highlights that end points for alcohol clinical trials should be associated with improvements in patient functioning.

caption.p: WHO risk drinking level (grams [g] of pure alcohol per day for males/females) by months from baseline, during treatment (months 1 to 4), and at each followâup month (months 5 to 16).

sec.p: Reduction in the WHO risk levels as a potential outcome measure has recently been studied in both populations of individuals receiving treatment for AUD (Aubin etÂ al., 2015; O'Malley etÂ al., 2018; Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017a, 2018) and a general population sample of alcohol drinkers (Hasin etÂ al., 2017; Knox etÂ al., 2018). Findings across studies show that reductions in WHO risk drinking levels are associated with significant differences between active medication treatments and placebo (Aubin etÂ al., 2015; Falk etÂ al., 2019; O'Malley etÂ al., 2018), improvements in physical health and the quality of life (Knox etÂ al., 2018, 2019; Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2018), reduced risk of alcohol dependence (Hasin etÂ al., 2017), and reductions in drinkingârelated consequences and improvements in mental health (Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017a).

sec.title: Current Study: Examining the Maintenance of Drinking Reduction Outcomes
sec.p: A major concern with nonabstinent drinking reduction outcomes is that they may not be maintained over time (Anton etÂ al., 2012). For example, the FDA recommends that clinical trials be 6Â months in duration based on the notion that âdrinking patterns over shorter durations of time, such as 12Â weeks, may not be stable or representative of future experienceâ (FDA, 2015, p. 5). Recent work in the field has supported the maintenance of lowârisk drinking outcomes, defined as not exceeding heavy drinking limits, over 1Â year (Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017b), 3Â years (Maisto etÂ al., 2007), and up to 9Â years following treatment (KlineâSimon etÂ al., 2017). However, the maintenance of the WHO risk drinking level reductions has not been studied extensively. Aubin and colleagues (2015) examined whether individuals who received nalmefene, compared to placebo, had a higher likelihood of achieving a 2âlevel reduction in WHO risk drinking level over a 6âmonth clinical trial, but did not examine the maintenance of the 2âlevel reduction outcome beyond 6Â months. Witkiewitz and colleagues (2017a, 2018) examined whether reductions in WHO risk levels during a 4âmonth clinical trial, the COMBINE study, predicted functioning for up to 1Â year following treatment, but did not examine whether reductions in WHO risk drinking levels themselves were maintained beyond the 4âmonth trial period. To address this gap in the literature, the current study examined the maintenance of the WHO risk level reductions for up to 1Â year following treatment. In line with FDA and EMA guidance, we also tested whether WHO risk level reductions were associated with functional improvement. We hypothesized that 1â and 2âlevel reductions in WHO risk levels would be maintained over time and that reductions in WHO risk levels would be associated with better functional outcomes over time.

sec.title: Participants and Procedures
sec.p: The data for the current study were from the COMBINE study (Anton etÂ al., 2006), a U.S. multisite, randomized, doubleâblind, placeboâcontrolled clinical trial that examined combinations of medications and behavioral interventions for treating alcohol dependence. All participants met the criteria for alcohol dependence based on DSMâIV (American Psychiatric Association, 1994) and had at least 2 heavy drinking days (defined as more than 3 drinks for women and more than 4 drinks for men) in a consecutive 30âday period within the 90Â days prior to the baseline assessment. Exclusion criteria were a current substance use disorder (other than nicotine or cannabis), a psychiatric disorder requiring medication, or unstable medical conditions. Participants in the current analyses (nÂ =Â 1,226) were randomized to receive: (i) active naltrexone (100Â mg/d) or placebo naltrexone; (ii) active acamprosate (3,000Â mg/d) or placebo acamprosate; or (iii) medication management (MM) or combined behavioral intervention with MM.

Followâup assessments were completed at the end of treatment (16Â weeks after baseline) and at 3 assessments after treatment: 10Â weeks posttreatment (26Â weeks after baseline), 36Â weeks posttreatment (52Â weeks after baseline), and 1Â year posttreatment (68Â weeks after baseline).

sec.title: Demographics
sec.p: Demographics, including age, sex, and race/ethnicity, were assessed using a selfâreport demographic questionnaire.

sec.title: Alcohol Consumption
sec.p: Daily standard drinks were measured using the Formâ90 (Miller, 1996) and Timeline FollowâBack interview (Sobell and Sobell, 1992). We calculated WHO risk drinking levels based on the number of standard drinks (defined as 0.6 ounces of absolute alcoholÂ =Â 14Â g of pure alcohol). WHO risk levels were calculated based on the average number of grams of alcohol consumed per day (i.e., drinks per day) over a specific time period (in the current study, we averaged over 1âmonth time periods). For the baseline period, we calculated the WHO risk drinking level using data from the month prior to the screening.

For all analyses, binary variables were included that reflected at least 1â or 2âlevel reductions in the WHO risk drinking levels from baseline to each month of treatment (postbaseline months 1 through 4) and from baseline to each followâup month (postbaseline months 5 through 16). The reference group for the 1âlevel reduction was no change or an increase in the WHO risk drinking level from baseline to the treatment/followâup months, and the reference group for the 2âlevel reduction was the 1âlevel reduction, no change, or increase in the WHO risk level from baseline to the treatment/followâup months.

Data from the Formâ90 (Miller, 1996) and Timeline FollowâBack interview (Sobell and Sobell, 1992) were also used to calculate the alcohol consumption outcomesâpercent heavy drinking days, percent drinking days, and drinks per drinking dayâat the end of treatment (postbaseline week 16), 10Â weeks posttreatment (postâbaseline week 26), 36Â weeks posttreatment (postbaseline week 52), and 1Â year posttreatment (postbaseline week 68).

sec.title: Functioning Outcomes
sec.p: Biological functioning was assessed at end of treatment (postbaseline week 16), 10Â weeks posttreatment (postbaseline week 26), and 36Â weeks posttreatment (postbaseline week 52), and included systolic blood pressure (SBP) and levels of the liver enzymes aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and Î³âglutamyltransferase (GGT). SBP was assessed at each clinic visit by clinical staff, and blood samples were sent to a central laboratory (Quintiles Laboratories, Marietta, GA) in which AST, ALT, and GGT clinical assays were performed utilizing automatic analyzer procedures. Lower levels of SBP, AST, ALT, and GGT are associated with better health outcomes (Kwo etÂ al., 2017; Strandberg and Pitkala, 2003).

Alcoholârelated consequences were assessed with the Drinker Inventory of Consequences (DrInC; Miller etÂ al., 1995), a 50âitem measure that uses a 4âlevel response scale (0Â =Â never and 3Â =Â daily or almost daily). The DrInC total score (based on 45 drinking consequences, excluding the 5 control items) was used to assess alcoholârelated consequences at the 1âyear followâup (Cronbach's Î±Â =Â 0.97).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive and inferential analyses were used to examine the maintenance of risk level reductions over time. Descriptive frequencies were used to determine the observed monthly prevalence of risk drinking level reductions. For inferential analyses, we used logistic regression and repeatedâmeasures mixed models to examine associations between WHO risk level reductions and functioning outcomes up to 1Â year posttreatment. First, we examined the association between risk level reductions achieved in the last month of treatment and at 1Â year posttreatment using logistic regression. Specifically, these analyses examined the odds of maintaining 1â and 2âlevel reductions at the 1âyear followâup assessment as a function of achieving 1â and 2âlevel reductions at the end of treatment, respectively. Second, to examine associations across all followâup months, general linear repeatedâmeasures mixed models with an identity link function were used to assess the association between WHO risk level reductions in each month over time and functional outcomes at each assessment over time. All mixed models were estimated using Mplus version 8 (MuthÃ©n and MuthÃ©n, 1998) using maximum likelihood estimation with robust estimation of standard errors to account for clustering within treatment sites (Yuan and Bentler, 2010). Missing data were accommodated via maximum likelihood estimation procedures, which provide an estimate of the varianceâcovariance matrix given all available data and allow for some missing data across months (Hallgren and Witkiewitz, 2013; Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2014). Consistent with prior analyses examining the WHO risk level reductions in the COMBINE study data (Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017a, 2018), we controlled for the following covariates in all analyses: age, sex, body mass index, smoking status, and baseline WHO risk level. All covariates were grandâmean centered.

sec.title: Sensitivity Analyses
sec.p: For all analyses, we performed 2 sets of sensitivity analyses. First, we reestimated all models with no change/increase imputed for individuals with missing drinking data, which was a small percent of the sample in each month (range of 1% in month 1 to 20% in month 16) given excellent retention in the COMBINE study (Anton etÂ al., 2006). This method of imputing âfailureâ for missing outcomes has been shown to produce biased estimates (Hallgren etÂ al., 2016); however, it is commonly recommended as a sensitivity analysis by regulatory agencies, including the FDA. Second, we examined the effect of excluding abstainers by conducting analyses among individuals who achieved 1â and 2âlevel reductions and were not abstinent. These analyses provided a test of whether reductions in drinking, short of abstinence, were associated with maintenance of risk level reductions (short of abstinence) and improvements in functioning over time.

sec.title: Descriptive Analyses
sec.p: Participants were mostly male (68.8%) and nonâHispanic white (76.7%) (black/African American [7.9%], Asian [0.3%], Hispanic (11.2%), American Indian/Alaska Native [1.3%)], multiracial [1.3%], and other race [1.2%]), with an average age of 44.4Â years (SDÂ =Â 10.2). At baseline, the majority of individuals (69.1%) were in the âvery high riskâ category (drinking over 101/61 [males/females] grams of pure alcohol per day on average) and there were no abstainers. As shown in Fig.Â 1, more than half of the sample was categorized as abstinent or low risk in every month following baseline (note that 1 person was missing drinking data at baseline for a baseline sample size of nÂ =Â 1,225).

The binary WHO risk level reduction variables were then created by calculating the reduction in risk drinking level from baseline to each month of treatment (months 1 to 4) and up to 12Â months posttreatment (months 5 to 16). The majority of the sample reduced their drinking from baseline to the last month of treatment (month 4) by at least 1 level (nÂ =Â 1,011, 88.5%) or at least 2 levels (nÂ =Â 881, 77.1%). The percentage of individuals who achieved at least 1â and at least 2âlevel reductions ranged from 79.0 to 84.2% and from 63.8 to 70.4%, respectively, across the followâup months (see Fig.Â 2).

caption.p: Percentage of participants achieving WHO risk level reductions from baseline to each month of treatment (months 1 to 4) and posttreatment (months 5 to 16).

sec.title: Logistic Regression
sec.p: Results from the logistic regression models indicated that reduction in WHO risk levels in the last month of treatment was significantly associated with at least 1â and 2âlevel reductions in WHO risk levels at 1Â year following treatment. Achieving at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction during the last month of treatment was associated with 9 to 10 times the odds of reporting at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction, respectively, at 1Â year following treatment (1âlevel reduction: Nagelkerke R 2Â =Â 0.20; B[SE]Â =Â 2.33 [0.24], pÂ <Â 0.001; odds ratio [OR] [95% confidence interval (CI)]Â =Â 10.25 [6.44, 16.29]; 2âlevel reduction: Nagelkerke R 2Â =Â 0.27; B[SE]Â =Â 2.24 [0.20], pÂ <Â 0.001; OR [95% confidence interval (CI)]Â =Â 9.40 [6.42, 13.78]). Among individuals who achieved at least a 1âlevel reduction by the end of treatment, 85.5% reported at least a 1âlevel reduction at the 1âyear followâup. Similarly, among individuals who achieved a least a 2âlevel reduction by the end of treatment, 77.8% reported at least a 2âlevel reduction at the 1âyear followâup.

sec.title: Linear Mixed Models
sec.p: Next, we examined whether 1â and 2âlevel reductions in WHO risk levels over time were associated with physical health, drinking consequences, and other measures of alcohol consumption over time. Descriptive statistics for functional outcomes by 1â and 2âlevel reduction groups are provided in TableÂ 1 (physical health outcomes) and TableÂ 2 (drinking outcomes). Results from the linear mixed models are provided in TableÂ 3. The reference group for the 1âlevel reduction showed no change or an increase in the WHO risk drinking level, and the reference group for the 2âlevel reduction showed a 1âlevel reduction, no change, or an increase in the WHO risk level from baseline to the treatment/followâup months. Unstandardized coefficients can be interpreted as the decrease in outcomes over time based on achieving at least a 1â and 2âlevel reduction over time, at the average level of covariates (covariate effects shown in TableÂ S1). For example, at least a 1âlevel reduction over time was associated with a 6.42Â mm Hg reduction in SBP (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 7.87Â IU/l reduction in AST (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 6.33Â IU/l reduction in ALT (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 26.92Â IU/l reduction in GGT (pÂ =Â 0.01), a reduction of 19.24 in DrInC total score (pÂ <Â 0.001), and lower drinking intensity and drinking frequency over time (all pÂ <Â 0.001). These findings reflect better functioning, on average over time, than in individuals with no change or an increase in the WHO risk drinking level over time. At least a 2âlevel reduction was associated with a 6.00Â mm Hg reduction in SBP (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 7.19Â IU/l reduction in AST (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 6.00Â IU/l reduction in ALT (pÂ <Â 0.001), a 21.84Â IU/l reduction in GGT (pÂ =Â 0.005), a reduction of 17.40 in DrInC total score (pÂ <Â 0.001), and lower drinking intensity and frequency (all pÂ <Â 0.001) than in individuals with a 1âlevel reduction, no change, or an increase in the WHO risk drinking level over time.

caption.p: Means (Standard Deviations [SDs]) for Each Physical Health Outcome by at Least 1â and 2âLevel Reductions at Each Assessment Time Point

tr.th: 1âlevel reduction, no change, or increase mean (SD)

fn.p: All numbers are observed (percentages are based on valid number of cases) with no imputation for missing data. Biomarker assessments were conducted at the end of treatment (week 16 after baseline) and at 2 assessments after treatment: 10Â weeks posttreatment (postbaseline week 26) and 36Â weeks posttreatment (postbaseline week 52). ALT, alanine aminotransferase; AST, aspartate aminotransferase; GGT, Î³âglutamyltransferase; IU/l, international units per liter; SBP, systolic blood pressure.

caption.p: Means (Standard Deviations SDs]) for Each Drinking Outcome by at Least 1â and 2âLevel Reductions at Each Assessment Time Point

tr.th: 1âlevel reduction, no change, or increase mean (SD)

fn.p: All numbers are observed (percentages are based on valid number of cases) with no imputation for missing data. Alcohol consumption and consequences were measured at weeks 16, 26, 52, and 68. DPDD, drinks per drinking day; DrInC, Drinker Inventory of Consequences Total Score; PHDD, percent heavy drinking days; PDD, percent drinking days.

caption.p: Linear Mixed Models Results for Functioning Outcomes Over Time Following Treatment as Predicted from 1â and 2âLevel Reductions Over Time (nÂ =Â 1,226) and Sensitivity Analyses with MissingÂ =Â Failure Imputation (nÂ =Â 1,226) and Excluding Abstainers (nÂ =Â 1,052)

fn.p: B (SE)Â =Â unstandardized regression coefficients (standard error), which can be interpreted as the decrease in outcomes based on achieving at least a 1â and 2âlevel reduction, at the average of all covariates (covariate effects reported in TableÂ S1); AST, aspartate aminotransferase; ALT, alanine aminotransferase; DPDD, drinks per drinking day; DrInC, Drinker Inventory of Consequences Total Score; GGT, Î³âglutamyltransferase; IU/l, international units per liter; PDD, percent drinking days; PHDD, percent heavy drinking days; SBP, systolic blood pressure. The reference group for the 1âlevel reduction was no change or an increase in the WHO risk drinking level from baseline to the treatment/followâup months, and the reference group for the 2âlevel reduction was the 1âlevel reduction, no change, or increase in the WHO risk level from baseline to the treatment/followâup months.

sec.title: Imputing Failure for Missing Data
sec.p: All models were reâestimated with failure imputed for missing data. For the 1âlevel reduction outcome, failure was defined as no change or an increase in WHO risk level. For the 2âlevel reduction outcome, failure was defined as a 1âlevel reduction, no change, or an increase in WHO risk level. The logistic regression models were nearly identical. Achieving at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction during the last month of treatment was associated with 9 to 10 times the odds of reporting at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction, respectively, at 1Â year posttreatment (1âlevel reduction: B[SE]Â =Â 2.33 [0.19], pÂ <Â 0.001; OR [95% CI]Â =Â 10.31 [7.01, 15.16]; 2âlevel reduction: B[SE]Â =Â 2.26 [0.18], pÂ <Â 0.001; OR [95% CI]Â =Â 9.55 [6.77, 13.47]). The results from the linear mixed models were substantively unchanged (see TableÂ 3).

sec.title: Excluding Abstainers
sec.p: Sensitivity analyses included only individuals who did not achieve abstinence (nÂ =Â 1,052). In this subgroup, the results of the logistic regression models with abstainers excluded were nearly identical to the prior models in which they were included. Achieving at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction during the last month of treatment (short of abstinence) was associated with greater than 8 times the odds of reporting at least a 1â or 2âlevel reduction (short of abstinence), respectively, at 1Â year posttreatment (1âlevel reduction: B[SE]Â =Â 2.39 [0.29], pÂ <Â 0.001; OR [95% CI]Â =Â 10.90 [6.14, 19.36]; 2âlevel reduction: B[SE]Â =Â 2.16 [0.26], pÂ <Â 0.001; OR [95% CI]Â =Â 8.69 [5.25, 14.39]). Of those who achieved at least a 1âlevel reduction by the end of treatment and were not abstinent, 80.4% reported at least a 1âlevel reduction by the 1âyear followâup. Similarly, of those who achieved a least a 2âlevel reduction by the end of treatment and were not abstinent, 69.5% reported at least a 2âlevel reduction at the 1âyear followâup. The results from the linear mixed models were similar (see TableÂ 3), although effects on functional outcomes were smaller with abstainers excluded. In particular, the effects of 1â and 2âlevel reductions on GGT were not significant with abstainers excluded.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The current study examined whether 1â and 2âlevel reductions in WHO risk levels were maintained over time in a large sample of individuals with alcohol dependence who received 4Â months of treatment and were followed for 12Â months after treatment. Consistent with study hypotheses, the 1â and 2âlevel reductions were maintained over time and associated with significant improvements in functioning over time up to 1Â year posttreatment. Results were robust to sensitivity analyses that imputed failure (e.g., no change or increase in WHO risk level) for missing data. The findings were also consistent when abstainers were excluded from the model, with 1 notable difference: At least 1â and 2âlevel reductions were not significantly associated with lower GGT.

The results from the current study are consistent with prior work demonstrating that lowârisk drinking outcomes are maintained up to and beyond 1Â year posttreatment (KlineâSimon etÂ al., 2017; Maisto etÂ al., 2007; Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017b). The current study makes an important new contribution by specifically focusing on WHO risk level reductions, showing that they are maintained across time and associated with improvements in functional outcomes over time.

The current study was limited by the data available in the COMBINE study, a clinical trial that did not include measures of all outcomes over time. For example, biomarkers were measured through 9Â months following treatment and were thus unavailable at the 1âyear followâup. More sensitive biomarkers, such as phosphatidylethanol and ethyl glucuronide, were not available in the COMBINE study data. Percent carbohydrateâdeficient transferrin, a biochemical marker that has previously been associated with the WHO risk level reductions (Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2018), was not measured at followâup months in the COMBINE study. Also, all drinking data were obtained by verbal report. These results were also limited to a 1âyear followâup, and there is the possibility that reductions would not be maintained for longer followâups, although there is evidence that reductions in drinking can be sustained over 3âyear and up to 9âyear followâups (KlineâSimon etÂ al., 2017; Maisto etÂ al., 2007). Future studies should extend the current analyses by examining the maintenance of WHO risk level reductions over longer periods of time and with other life functional assessments, such as medical outcomes and costs.

The current findings build on other recent studies that have provided support for the reduction in WHO risk drinking levels as primary outcomes in clinical trials (Falk etÂ al., 2019; Hasin etÂ al., 2017; Knox etÂ al., 2018, 2019; Witkiewitz etÂ al., 2017a, 2018). We found that 1â and 2âlevel WHO risk drinking level reductions were maintained across a 1âyear followâup for most participants and reductions in WHO risk drinking levels over time corresponded to statistically significant and clinically meaningful differences in blood pressure, liver enzyme levels, alcohol consumption, and drinkingârelated consequences, as compared to those among individuals who did not achieve reductions.

Sensitivity analyses provided further support for the maintenance of drinking reductions, even when abstainers were excluded from the analysis. These findings are particularly important because the majority of individuals with AUD who are seeking treatment prefer nonabstinence goals (DeMartini etÂ al., 2014; Haug etÂ al., 2018; Ryan etÂ al., 2017). Moreover, many people with AUD do not seek treatment because they do not want to completely abstain from alcohol (ParkâLee etÂ al., 2017). More individuals with AUD may be interested in seeking treatment if they are aware of the possibility that drinking reduction goals are achievable, sustainable, and associated with improvements in functioning (Mann etÂ al., 2017; van Amsterdam and van den Brink, 2013). The expansion of treatment options to be more inclusive of drinking reduction goals is critically important. The current findings show a high probability that such drinking reductions are maintained over time.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Dr. Kranzler is named as an inventor on PCT patent application #15/878640 entitled: âGenotypeâguided dosing of opioid agonists,â filed January 24, 2018. Dr. Mann received honoraria for consultancies from Pfizer. Dr. Hasin is Principal Investigator of a study funded by inVentiv Health Consulting that combines support from:Â Actavis, Inc.; Endo Pharmaceuticals; Janssen Pharmaceuticals, Inc.; Mallinckrodt, LLC; Pfizer, Inc.; Purdue Pharma, L.P.; Rhodes Pharmaceuticals, L.P.; Roxane Laboratories, Inc.; and Zogenix, Inc. Dr. O'Malley reports being a consultant or an advisory board member of Alkermes, Amygdala, Indivior, Mitsubishi Tanabe, and Opiant, and a NIDA Clinical Trials Network DSMB member with honorarium from the Emmes Corporation and donated study medications from Astra Zeneca and Novartis. Dr. Anton has been a consultant in recent past for Insys, Allergan, and Life Epigenetics, has received honorarium from Alkermes for grant reviews, and currently has grant funding from Laboratorio Farmaceutica CT. Drs. Witkiewitz, Kranzler, Mann, Hasin, O'Malley, and Anton are members of the American Society of Clinical Psychopharmacology's Alcohol Clinical Trials Initiative (ACTIVE Group) The ACTIVE Workgroup has been supported previously, but not in the past 36 months, by Abbott/Abbvie, Ethypharm, GSK, Janssen, Lilly, Pfizer, and Schering Plough, but in the past 36 months its activities were supported by Alkermes, Amygdala Neurosciences, Arbor Pharmaceuticals, Indivior, Lundbeck, Mitsubishi, and Otsuka. Drs. Falk and Litten have no disclosures.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This study was funded by the U.S. National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (R01AA022328). In addition to the authors, the following individuals are or were members of the Alcohol Clinical Trials Initiative (ACTIVE) Workgroup and provided intellectual input during attendance at Workgroup meetings: Joanne Fertig, PhD, and Megan Ryan, PhD, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Tanya Ramey, MD, PhD, and David McCann, PhD, National Institute on Drug Abuse; Didier Meulien, MD, Lundbeck SAS; Anne Andorn, MD, and Jay Graham, MD, Indivior; Roger Meyer, MD, Best Practice Project Management, Inc.; HenriâJean Aubin, MD, ParisâSud Medical School; Charles O'Brien, MD, PhD, University of Pennsylvania; Bernard Silverman, MD, Alkermes, Inc.; Francoise Trinquet, MD, and Benjamin Zakine, MD, Ethypharm. Lindsay Snyder and Sarah Timm (ASCP) provided important administrative support to the ACTIVE Workgroup.
